creditline: Museum purchase, Gift of Dr. and Mrs. Harvey Rothberg
inscribed:
Two lines in Latin inscribed in plate, below image center: PLECTENTES CORONAM DE SPINIS POSVERVNT SVPER VAPTVT EIVS, […] ergo Martinus Vanden Enden dedicabat.

Inscribed and signed in plate, lower left corner: Ant. Van Dyck pinxit. / S.A. Belswert fecut.

Inscribed in plate, lower right corner: {Marinus vulum Enden / excudit cum Privilige?]

makers.displaydate: 1599–1641; born Antwerp, Belgium; died London, England
makers.displaymaker: after Anthony van Dyck, 1599–1641; born Antwerp, Belgium; died London, England

texts.textentryhtml: This engraving by Schelte Adams Bolswert records (in reverse) a large canvas by the painter Anthony van Dyck that was formerly in the Kaiser-Friedrich Museum, Berlin, where it was destroyed in 1945. Like his teacher Peter Paul Rubens, Van Dyck relied on reproductive prints to disseminate his paintings to a large audience. The composition’s focal point is the seated Christ, whose hair is violently pulled by an armored soldier as he places a crown of thorns on Christ’s head. In comparison with Van Dyck’s adjacent Mocking of Christ, this earlier interpretation of the same Passion episode is more theatrical, featuring more torturers and a specific, dungeon-like setting, complete with a barred window.
